title: The Top 2026 Denim Trends Ask You to Take Up Space
text:
The Top 2026 Denim Trends Ask You to Take Up Space

Fashion is starting to undergo a major shift. In 2026, as with beauty moving away from the pared-down â€œclean girlâ€ makeup trend, fashion is moving away from the mainstream minimalism of recent years. In its place is a moodier and maximal sensibility. What does this mean for jeans? Denim trends are going to inspire you to have way more fun as you get dressed in the months ahead.

One theme in particular is ruling over all popular 2026 denim: exaggeration. Prepare to take up space in baggy, inflated silhouettes with playful proportions. â€œComfort is a huge factor, but thereâ€™s also something about the relaxed look that just feels more modern right now,â€ Pistola Denim founder Grace Na tells Refinery29.

Skinny jeans arenâ€™t completely out of the picture â€” donâ€™t let us stop you if theyâ€™re your favorites â€” but tight, figure-hugging styles certainly wonâ€™t be dominating the conversation this year. Ultimately: â€œJeans should flex with how you feel, where youâ€™re going, and who you want to be that day or even that moment of your day,â€ Lâ€™Agence fashion director Tara Rudes Dann says.Â 

Ahead, meet the top 2026 denim trends to welcome into your wardrobe, as well as some useful shopping picks. But this isnâ€™t an experiment you have to test alone: We spoke to the forces behind some of our favorite brands to break down the looks, why theyâ€™re popular, and how to style them.

DashDividers_1_500x100

Barrel Jeans, With A Twist

Barrel-leg jeans came into the zeitgeist just a few years ago as a funky denim trend with questionable longevity. Yet naysayers should take heed that this silhouette is very much here to stay. This fashion-forward style features a very noticeable curve from the hip to the ankle, and that distinct shape is only going to keep getting more visible in the months ahead.

Itâ€™s worth noting that barrel jeans are also sometimes called a horseshoe or balloon jean, though the latter is a more exaggerated version of the look. â€œIt plays with volume in a really fresh way and adds a bit of fashion energy without feeling too intimidating,â€ Pistolaâ€™s Na says of the barrel-adjacent balloon.

Rather than intimidate you, you might find that barrel jeans are incredibly versatile when it comes to styling. Pair them with a blazer, polo shirt, and heels for an office-ready look, or try them with a cool-girl leather jacket and sneakers for brunch with friends.

DashDividers_1_500x100

Wide-Leg Jeans

Weâ€™ve been seeing lots of volume in pants and jeans from plenty of brands, so itâ€™s no surprise that wide-leg denim will be all over your social feeds and in your favorite stores in 2026. This comfortable cut was, after all, the viral opening look in Chanelâ€™s MÃ©tiers dâ€™art 2026 show â€”Â you know, the one held in a New York City subway station. Rather than hugging the body anywhere, this yearâ€™s class of wide-leg jeans shoot out from the waistband. These baggier silhouettes look great on everyone, and especially for petite wearers, a higher-sitting waist can help elongate the legs.

â€œThe baggy jean can be styled with a heel for a tailored look or worn with a sneaker for a weekend-ready look,â€ Paige co-founder and creative director Paige Adams-Geller says. The degree of baggy? Well, thatâ€™s buyerâ€™s choice, and thereâ€™s a range of whatâ€™s available.

DashDividers_1_500x100

Straight-Leg & Cigarette Jeans

Skinny jeans may not be as ubiquitous as they were during the hipster heyday of the 2010s, but skinny-ish silhouettes are still in vogue. Straight-leg and cigarette jeans (darlings of the â€˜80s and â€˜90s) are the top nominees here. Though these two silhouettes are very similar, thanks to their slim fit that goes straight down the leg, they differ in one key spot: cigarette jeans taper at the ankle.

The range of trends in the denim space are also a net positive for both your closet and a denim brandâ€™s creativity. â€œIt is exciting for us as designers but also for women because they can wear whatever suits them,â€ Tim Kaeding, co-founder of Mother Denim, tells Refinery29. â€œIt isnâ€™t like previous decades where one fit is dominating everything. It really is a cross-section between skinny and baggy.â€

Straight-leg and cigarette jeans work best in outfits that are all about clean lines â€”Â for one such example, look to Valentinoâ€™s Spring/Summer 2026 collection. Try adding a structured blazer or, for balance, a soft cardigan. If youâ€™re on the shorter side, it can be extra helpful to have these jeans tailored at the hem to ensure thereâ€™s no pooling at your feet. In a pinch, wearing heels or using some iron-on hemming tape can also help.

DashDividers_1_500x100

Maxing Out

Mirroring the longer and looser denim styles ruling the year, skirts are going midi and maxi. (If you love your denim mini skirt, simply stash it in storage â€” weâ€™re sure itâ€™ll come back in a few years.) The coolest denim skirts feature unique details like cool-enhancing asymmetric hems. Gravitating toward a more classic shape? Try a new-to-your-closet denim wash to mix things up.

There are endless ways to style these skirts, whether girly, sporty, or something else. We like pairing ours with a moto jacket and combat boots for some edge. A button-up, on the other hand, projects a more polished vibe.

DashDividers_1_500x100

Contemporary Bootcut Jeans

Raise your hand if you gotÂ  rid of any bootcut jeans you had left over from the early aughts. (We did too.) Yet, while the style is one of the major denim trends to watch in 2026, the new class of bootcut styles is far more modern than the jeans of yore. Instead of a distinct slim-to-flare cut, the refreshed bootcut is more subtle. Best of all, comfortable high-waisted styles are as easy to source as low-rise inseams that all but scream â€œY2K.â€Â 

â€œSheâ€™s confident, sexy and incredibly flattering,â€ Lâ€™Agenceâ€™s Rudes Dann says of the style. After all: â€œwomen want jeans that celebrate curves and command attention.â€

Making bootcut jeans feel current is also about how you style themÂ â€”Â and no, you arenâ€™t expected to only wear them with boots. Rock these jeans with loafers or pointed-toe heels for an elevated silhouette. For a more casual outfit, pair them with a white T-shirt, cool jacket, and skinny-soled sneakers.

DashDividers_1_500x100

Think Beyond Jeans

Your legs arenâ€™t the only place where denim can make a maximum impact. Expect to see designers use the material for shirts, dresses, and accessories in 2026.Â 

Want to rock a Canadian tuxedo or channel Britney Spearsâ€™ iconic denim-princess ballgown? Thatâ€™ll be easier than ever as brands continue to crank out shoes, bags, and outerwear all made with denim. Denim cowboy boots? Yes, (and thank you, BeyoncÃ©). A crossbody bag made from the same material? Never no.

â€œDenim jackets are showing up in sharper shapes in addition to the classic jean jacket,â€ Rudes Dann says of the all-denim everything trend of 2026. â€œThink bomber silhouettes and tailored blazers that feel structured but still easy and chic.â€

DashDividers_1_500x100

Jorts

Think of todayâ€™s most popular jorts â€”Â a portmanteau for jean shorts â€” as wide-leg denimâ€¦ for warmer weather. This style, which usually fits loose and hits below the knee if not right above it, is a seasonal interpretation of this yearâ€™s theme of comfort and ease. Style these with a snug shirt for proportional balance, or wear them with an oversized graphic tee to go full Adam Sandler.

DashDividers_1_500x100

Decorations & Details

Understated and unembellished jeans wonâ€™t ever lose their luster, but denim with an extra bit of flair is quickly becoming a favorite for the style-obsessed. Utility-inspired styles, like carpenter jeans, are staying mainstream, as are spunky styles that are decked out in embellishments. Pair these with a basic tee, jacket, and kicks to really let the jeans shine.

text:

JennetteÂ McCurdyâ€™sÂ memoirÂ Iâ€™mÂ Glad My Mom DiedÂ leftÂ me in tears. So, when I heard that the actress turned author was releasing a new book, her first novel, I was excited. IÂ spokeÂ with McCurdyÂ over ZoomÂ to discuss how femaleÂ rage is one of theÂ novelâ€™sÂ major themes,Â whyÂ it was important for her toÂ writeÂ Half His Age, and theÂ TV adaptation ofÂ Iâ€™mÂ Glad My Mom Died.

Refinery29:Â Jennette, after writing your amazing memoir,Â Iâ€™mÂ Glad My Mom Died,Â how did you decide that this was the nextÂ step in your journey as aÂ writer?Â Â 

JennetteÂ McCurdy:Â Oh boy. I haveÂ a veryÂ writerlyÂ answer to this. I used to not understand when authors talked this way,Â butÂ now I completely understand. ItÂ was a thing that demanded to be written.Â You know, I was actually writing another thing, andÂ Half His AgeÂ was kind of like pushing itself up on me, and I couldnâ€™t stop thinking about Waldo.Â I said,Â â€œYouÂ know, Iâ€™ll give it aÂ week.â€Â Iâ€™llÂ let it run itsÂ course.Â Iâ€™llÂ probably growÂ tired of it, and thenÂ Iâ€™llÂ just go back to this other thing. And then,Â 30 daysÂ later, I had a first draft, and IÂ immediatelyÂ went into a second draft, then a third, and fourth, until it was just finished. There was no choice. AndÂ I thinkÂ thatâ€™sÂ always a good sign, right?Â For me, thatâ€™sÂ alwaysÂ anÂ experience with creativity.Â The oneÂ thatâ€™sÂ pushing itself upÂ onÂ me,Â itâ€™sÂ the one that gets done.Â Thatâ€™sÂ just how it goes.

How much does Waldo believe that she has this relationship with her teacher underÂ herÂ control? And why is it important for you to show thatÂ nuance even thoughÂ sheâ€™sÂ clearlyÂ notÂ inÂ control becauseÂ sheâ€™sÂ a minor?Â 

JM:Â I really triedÂ to avoid being moralistic in the writing itselfÂ and to be more subtle than that.Â Okay, thisÂ isnâ€™tÂ very subtle,Â butÂ Iâ€™llÂ say it.Â Waldo is very aggressiveÂ and is very forward andÂ is,Â at times, you know, throwingÂ herselfÂ at this man. He is still a 40-year-oldÂ man who should knowÂ better. I neverÂ statedÂ in the book, butÂ Iâ€™llÂ state itÂ here now. I reallyÂ wanted to showÂ thisÂ youngÂ woman who really believes she is in control and is really fighting to be in control and clawing for some form of power.Â Sheâ€™sÂ still so vulnerable.Â Sheâ€™sÂ still at an ageÂ that isÂ so vulnerable. And yet atÂ thatÂ age,Â youâ€™reÂ not necessarilyÂ aware of your limitations, of theÂ places whereÂ youâ€™reÂ particularly naive or susceptible to outside influences. YouÂ donâ€™tÂ know those things.Â I really think itÂ was so importantÂ to me to show it through her eyes completely because. Most of us reading it areÂ goingÂ toÂ be a bit older, and we know whatÂ itâ€™sÂ like toÂ be 17. We know what itâ€™sÂ like not toÂ beÂ inÂ thatÂ naive position, and to be that susceptible to influence. We haveÂ all been there. It was so important to me to do it completely through herÂ eyes.Â Â Â 

Yes. We also know whatÂ itâ€™sÂ like to think we know everything when we really know nothing.Â Youâ€™veÂ saidÂ that one of the main themes of this book isÂ femaleÂ rage. What do you mean when you say female rage? And why do you feelÂ itâ€™sÂ important to explore that theme?Â 

JM:Â Thank you forÂ thisÂ question.Â IÂ would love to hear what female rageÂ is to you. Female rage to me is having your boundaries violatedÂ over and overÂ andÂ over and over and overÂ again, and not having access to the language, the tools to advocate for yourself. Being afraid to advocate for yourself. Told not to advocate for yourself, to be polite, to be nice, to make things easy, to not be difficult.Â So,Â you continue doing that and playing thatÂ roleÂ over and over again.Â Then your boundaries are still violated over and over and over again, and it compounds for years until, inevitably, the rage starts to crop up and come out in unexpected ways.Â Thereâ€™sÂ no choice but toÂ start confronting it and understanding not only its roots, but also how to ideally channel it properly moving forward. This was such an important themeÂ forÂ me to explore.Â IÂ think we allÂ have a lot of female rage. You tell me if you disagree. Do you have it?Â 

IÂ do not disagree.Â 

JM:Â Itâ€™sÂ somethingÂ we all know so well, and yet IÂ havenâ€™tÂ really felt the social conversationÂ go there the way I wish it would. I thinkÂ thereâ€™sÂ soÂ much value in our rage if we can access it, ifÂ weâ€™reÂ not hiding it and doing the thing where weâ€™reÂ suppressing and beingÂ polite andÂ prettyÂ andÂ niceÂ and whatever. IfÂ weâ€™reÂ able to go,Â Iâ€™mÂ fucking angry, and hereâ€™s whatÂ  Iâ€™m angry about. Oh my God,Â thatâ€™sÂ whenÂ itÂ movesÂ through you.Â Thatâ€™s when it leads to decisions you can make that areÂ actually helpful for your life.Â And Waldo is not there yet.Â Sheâ€™sÂ not atÂ the place where she can make those helpful decisions. She is 17. Sheâ€™sÂ in theÂ throes of it, and sheÂ doesnâ€™tÂ even realize the extent of it. And it is fueling herÂ decisions so much without herÂ even realizing it. Her drive for sex. Her need forÂ Korgy.Â HerÂ need forÂ things. For clothing. All of itÂ is soÂ chargedÂ byÂ rage and shame.Â I really hope itÂ willÂ open upÂ a broader conversation about what we canÂ doÂ with our rage and how we can find empoweringÂ ways ofÂ utilizingÂ it.Â Â 

Yes,Â I think thatÂ is something we should talkÂ more about.Â We should be allowed to feel pure anger. There are so many things set up to make us angry, and I should be allowed to curse somebody out.Â Â 

JM:Â There are some lovely men. AllÂ gaysÂ are great. There are someÂ straightsÂ who areÂ lovely.Â [laughs]Â Iâ€™mÂ with an amazing one.Â Â ButÂ I think a lot of times, their fear of our emotions can really cause us toÂ sort of suppressÂ andÂ wannaÂ beÂ politeÂ andÂ keep going in that inauthentic way.Â Who can hold our rage? A)Â OurselvesÂ andÂ B)Â Other women.Â I have never felt more at ease and safe in my rage than when I explore it with other women and talk about it. Having those deep, thoughtful conversations about what it is weâ€™re so angry about, what the root of it is, what it might be actively thatâ€™s in our life thatâ€™s causing it to resurface, and how we can move forward in a way that is productive and healthy.Â 

What is the best way for us to express our female rage?Â Â 

JM:Â I think it can be different for everybody. Something that might beÂ somewhat universal,Â Iâ€™dÂ say, is having a creative outlet. For me, itâ€™s writing. I think I write really effectively fromÂ a place of anger.Â Itâ€™sÂ when I do the most charged writing that I think connects the most. It can be a variety of things, butÂ I think creativityÂ is one place. A genuine conversation is another place for it.Â Surprise!Â [laughs]Â ThatÂ shouldnâ€™tÂ be shocking.Â Just talking it out and not pretending to be happy, happy, happy and grateful, grateful, gratefulÂ all the time. That is crazy making.

It is, as they call it, toxic positivity.Â Â Â 

JM:Â Yes.Â Â Â 

If you could explainÂ HalfÂ HisÂ AgeÂ using the five senses, what would they be? For example, it sounds like this, it feels like this.Â Â Â 

JM:Â Ooh, okay. It feels like skin. Sweaty skin,Â particularlyÂ sweaty, hairy skin. It sounds like a train, like the force of a train. Potentially aboutÂ to crash. We see a train coming the opposite way. The two trains are coming at the same time.Â Thatâ€™sÂ what it sounds like.Â 

If train A startsÂ here and train B starts there, when will they collide?Â Â Â 

JM:Â Exactly. What does it smell like? My mind went to sweat again, butÂ Iâ€™llÂ say it smells likeâ€¦Â IÂ canâ€™tÂ say where my mind wasÂ [laughs].Â Iâ€™llÂ say it:Â itÂ smells like a certain bodily fluid. It tastes like sour patch kids. And it looks likeÂ desolate landscapes of Alaska, and thenÂ Iâ€™mÂ thinking extreme close-ups of sex.Â Itâ€™sÂ not likeÂ weâ€™reÂ seeing a romanticized shot whereÂ itâ€™sÂ hot and steamy.Â Itâ€™sÂ likeÂ weâ€™reÂ seeing a close-up of an arm.Â Weâ€™reÂ seeing that gut.Â Weâ€™reÂ justÂ seeing the body hanging by itself.Â Weâ€™reÂ seeing cellulite, weâ€™reÂ seeingÂ makeup-lessÂ faces,Â weâ€™reÂ seeing lips, andÂ weâ€™reÂ seeing drool. JustÂ kind of theÂ visceral,Â disgusting elements of sex. Â Â 

What is it like to be so vulnerable publicly and share so much of yourself? Does it make it easier or harder thatÂ youâ€™veÂ been in the spotlight for so long?Â Â Â 

JM:Â Iâ€™m really glad that I had yearsÂ whereÂ I was not in the spotlight.Â No social media app was on my phone. I was in aÂ caveÂ writingÂ for quite a few years. Not even considering the public eye in any way, shape, or form. And then being back into it as an adult has been really interesting, fun, and at times complicated, but I do leadÂ withÂ vulnerability.Â Honesty is an important valueÂ ofÂ mine. Authenticity.
